p: Additionally, previous results using aqueous and ethanolic extracts from T. polium aerial parts have shown moderate anti-rinderpest virus [ 80]. In 2014, Ansari and co-workers [ 81] reported that T. polium was a rich source of rosmarinic acid (1.8%, w/w), weak cytotoxic activity (maximum non-toxic concentration = 1000 μg/mL), and anti-Herpes Simplex Virus-1 (HSV-1)—affected by the exposure time and the concentration of the extract used. In fact, after one hour of cell infection, 93.1% of HSV-1 were inhibited by 50 μg/mL of plant extract. This percentage of inhibition reached 100% after one hour of exposure to 100 and 250 μg/mL of felty germander extract [ 81]. This activity was correlated to the high concentration of rosmarinic acid, a phenolic compound known to possess antiviral activity [ 82].
